docs.lead_paragraph: A woman who is a frequent patient at the Shands Teaching Hospital in Gainesville, Fla., recently returned to the emergency room and asked for drugs to alleviate chronic pain in her hip. Because doctors thought she was ''hooked on the needle,'' sometimes claiming relief even before the hypodermic was withdrawn, the attending physician ordered a nurse to give her a placebo. The nurse refused because she felt it was unethical to deceive the patient. So another nurse, who agreed with doctors that the cure justified the lie, injected the woman with three cubic centimeters of saline solution. Minutes later the patient went home, saying she felt much better. ''I don't feel guilty, it wasn't malicious,'' the nurse who administered the saline shot said in an interview. ''We ruled out organic causes of her pain. It is one of the tools of medicine.''

headline.main: VALUE OF THE PLACEBO BEING ARGUED ON ETHICAL GROUNDS

docs.lead_paragraph: Dr. McKeen Cattell, whose research showed the effect of digitalis drugs on heart muscle, died Tuesday at the Castle Point Veterans Administration Hospital in Beacon, N.Y. He was 91 years old and lived in Cold Spring, N.Y. Dr. Cattell joined the department of physiology at Cornell University Medical College in 1924 after graduating from the Harvard Medical School. In 1937, he became chairman of the department of pharmacology where, with the late Dr. Harry Gold, he initiated studies on the pharmacology of digitalis, a substance originally extracted from the foxglove plant.

headline.main: LED STUDY ON ACTION OF DIGITALIS ON HEART

docs.lead_paragraph: Following are excerpts from Gov. William A. O'Neill's budget address to the General Assembly today: In preparing the budget I am proposing today, a process that has occupied me for more hours and days than I can count, I have used two basic guidelines. First, I am determined that this budget will keep faith with the people of Connecticut and meet their real needs. We have a proud heritage in this state of caring and commitment, and of being leaders for the nation. I do not intend ignore that heritage. I believe the people of Connecticut expect and demand strong leadership, especially during difficult times. This administration will honor its commitment to the social contract with our people. To meet these needs, my second guideline was the work of the Bipartisan Commission on State Tax Revenue and Related Fiscal Policy. I am recommending a general-fund budget of $3.552 billion, an increase of $320.5 million, or 9.9 percent, over this year's estimated spending. This is a cut of more than $200 million from the amount I began working with nearly three months ago.

headline.main: EXCERPTS FROM ADDRESS ON CONNECTICUT BUDGET

docs.lead_paragraph: Anyone whose income tax deductions exceed $2,300 - or $3,400 for married couples filing jointly - can save money by itemizing. Because deductions for medical expenses and casualty losses are being tightened up considerably in the 1983 tax year, this is a better time for itemizers than next year will be. Many people find that the best way to reduce tax liability is to pay attention to - and keep records of - all the itemized deductions they are eligible for. State and local taxes, medical expenses, charity contributions, casualty losses, mortgage and credit card interest costs, union dues and the cost of professional help in filling out tax returns are all deductible items.

headline.main: ITEMIZING DEDUCTIONS: GOOD RECORDS ARE VITAL
